metadata.sermon_start_end: The combination of heavenly grace and earthly fear is one of the most powerful recurrent themes in Scripture. Sometimes the word “fear” in English means something more like “reverence” or “awe,” but very often it means just plain “terror” or “dread.” [...] In this sacrifice, toward which the church begins to move in Epiphany, there is a whole new world where everything is changed, where hope appears in the midst of hopelessness, where the promises of God break through to the exiles, where even the smallest acts of human charity signify the coming of the time when the dead will be raised, and all our sins and foolishness will be no more.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails Dekker’s primary formal requirement by treating four distinct passages across two separate homiletic reflections. It functions as a thematic 'speech about the gospel' and 'fear' rather than an exposition of one specific pericope. It misses the 'NOWHERE else' quality by harmonizing texts into a general biblical idea.
quotes: Today we have two readings about the fear of the Lord, one from the Old Testament and one from the New.
Luke’s story is a parallel to the epiphanies of YHWH in the Old Testament.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Choose either Judges 6 or Luke 5. Do not harmonize them. Identify what is unique to Gideon's specific interaction with the angel that is absent from Peter's experience.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The preacher shows adequate knowledge of the historical context (Babylonian exile, the nature of 'angel of the Lord' in the OT). However, the exegesis remains at the level of narrative summary rather than deep linguistic or theological 'exposition' as Dekker demands.
quotes: This hopelessness must have assailed the people of Israel during the time of the Babylonian exile in the fourth century BC.
In the Old Testament, 'the angel of the Lord' is equivalent to the Lord himself.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Move beyond narrative retelling. Analyze the specific Hebrew or Greek nuances that reveal the 'newness' of the Word in these specific verses.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: While the sermon attempts concreteness with modern examples (subway, income tax, crack addicts), these often function as illustrative anecdotes rather than a rigorous application of the text's specific claim to the hearer's zeitgeist. It borders on general truths about 'hope'.
quotes: doing our income tax, riding the subway, there may suddenly come an irruption of grace
The young woman who lives in the Port Authority Bus Terminal has been a crack addict
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Avoid using the 'crack addict' as a distant object. Apply the text's specific judgment and grace to the concrete spiritual condition of the actual congregation present.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a traditional 'block' structure: retelling the story followed by a 'lesson' or application. The hearer is not drawn into the text as it is being expounded; they are given a lecture on the text and then a separate reflection.
quotes: Two stories: one about Gideon, one about Peter... [Transition to:] Grace is terrifying.
Here is an image. The young woman who lives in the Port Authority...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Abolish the 'story-then-lesson' structure. Apply the text's specific details immediately as they are being expounded.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: This is a strong point. The preacher takes 'misery' (sin, terror, dread) seriously and does not soften it. Redemption is clearly placed outside the self (extra nos).
quotes: You and I are deep in sin. We clutch our privileges to ourselves and are increasingly indifferent to the suffering of others
He does not ask us what we are doing to make ourselves better; he just gives the gift.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Ensure the 'gratitude' (the third part) is more clearly linked to the specific text rather than a general 'feeling blessed'.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon acknowledges the possibility of being lost ('we would be lost'), but it lacks the 'narrow way' urgency Dekker requires. The 'two ways' are mentioned as a concept rather than a call to decision.
quotes: If your rebelliousness and mine were allowed to play themselves out to the end, we would be lost
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: The preacher must confront the hearer with the choice: the destination of the life design. The 'lostness' must be more than a hypothetical 'if'.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is clearly the telos. The sermon moves toward the cross and emphasizes that salvation is found only in Him. The doctrine of the two natures is implicit in the discussion of the Baptism.
quotes: God has become man... has come down in the person of his Son to be dunked in the muddy waters
Christ who is his life [implied in:] paying in his own body the price of sin
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Explicitly link the specific Old Testament text (Gideon) to Christ without falling into generalities.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 14-15 minutes, the sermon fails Dekker's 20-minute minimum. It lacks the 'breadth' required for true homiletic depth, opting for multiple short reflections instead of one deep exposition.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Focus on one text and expand the exposition and application to at least 20 minutes to allow for 'depth'.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily due to its lack of focus on a single, specific Bible passage and its insufficient length. It functions as a thematic survey of 'Epiphany' rather than a rigorous exposition. While it handles the 'three parts' (misery, redemption, gratitude) with theological sobriety and avoids moralism, it remains too fragmented to achieve the 'present of revelation' Dekker describes.
strengths: Theological sobriety regarding human sin and the necessity of external grace.
Avoidance of 'soft' or purely psychological preaching; the 'terror' of God is maintained.
Clear Christocentric focus in the second half.
weaknesses: Lack of formal unity; treats too many passages at once.
Insufficient duration (under 20 minutes) prevents exegetical and applicative depth.
Separation of exposition and application into distinct blocks.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: According to Dekker’s definition, this is not yet a sermon. It is a series of theological reflections or a 'speech about biblical themes.' To become a sermon, it must commit to the 'monogamy' of one text and allow that text to dictate a specific, non-general truth over a sustained period of at least 20 minutes.
